transcription.text: / Φλά(βιον) Σεβῆρον, τὸν λαμ(πρότατον) ἀνθύπατον, / σωτῆρα καὶ εὐεργέτην τῶν Ἑλλήνων, / Κάλλυς πρωτεύων τὸν ἴδιον εὐεργέτην, / Ψ(ηφίσματι) Β(ουλῆς).

textHtml.div:
Φλά(βιον) Σεβῆρον, τὸν λαμ(πρότατον) ἀνθύπατον,
σωτῆρα καὶ εὐεργέτην τῶν Ἑλλήνων,
Κάλλυς πρωτεύων τὸν ἴδιον εὐεργέτην,
Ψ(ηφίσματι) Β(ουλῆς).

textEpidoc.ab:
Φλά(βιον) Σεβῆρον, τὸν λαμ(πρότατον) ἀνθύπατον,
σωτῆρα καὶ εὐεργέτην τῶν Ἑλλήνων,
Κάλλυς πρωτεύων τὸν ἴδιον εὐεργέτην,
Ψ(ηφίσματι) Β(ουλῆς).

transcription.bibliography: Zoumbaki, S. B., Einblick in das spätantike Elis: Eine unpublizierte Inschrift zu Ehren des Prokonsuls Flavius Severus, Zeitschrift für Papyrologie und Epigraphik 164, 2008, 123-130
transcription.commentary: INSCRIPTION In four lines: Φλά(βιον) Σεβῆρον, τὸν λαμ(πρότατον) ἀνθύπατον, / σωτῆρα καὶ εὐεργέτην τῶν Ἑλλήνων, / Κάλλυς πρωτεύων τὸν ἴδιον εὐεργέτην, / Ψ(ηφίσματι) Β(ουλῆς) 'To Flavius Severus, of clarissimus rank, governor (proconsul), saviour and benefactor oft he Greeks. Kallus, leader (proteuon) (set this up to) his own benefactor. By decree of the council.' Letter height: 0.25 – 6 cm. DESCRIPTION (from Zoumbaki 2008, and the published, image) Low rectangular base with mouldings at top and bottom, H 40, W 74, D 72 cm. The top face of the base is finished with a point. At its centre it has a large oval cavity for the plinth of the marble statue. The first line of the inscription is carved on the upper moulding. The statue that was found along with the inscription was a reused marble himation statue of the early imperial period (<l>2696<n>LSA-2696<k>). PROVENANCE AND CURRENT LOCATION The inscription and statue were found in 2003 during excavations in Elis. When excavated, it was standing in situ at the south western corner of the gate ( propylon) leading to the temple for the imperial cult. This was the crossroads of two major streets of the ancient city. There is no published record of the monuments’ current location; both, statue and inscribed base are presumably in the Elis museum. HONORAND, AWARDER AND DATE Flavius Severus, the honorand, was governor (proconsul, Gr. anthupatos, line 1) of the province of Achaea. The province is not recorded in the inscription, but he is praised as ‘saviour and benefactor of the Greeks’ (line 2). He is only known from our inscription (but see below, next paragraph). Zoumbaki, the editor of the inscription, dated it to the 4th century on base of the letter forms which she compared to an Athenian building inscription recording the proconsul (Flavius?) Severus Aetius, datable to 396-408 (Sironen 1997, 112-14 no. 38; IG II/III(2) ). Both, Severus Aetius in Athens and the proconsul Flavius Severus of our inscription bear the name Severus; they are just possibly identical. Kallus, the awarder, is styled ‘proteuon’ in our inscription. This title is used to denote excellent social status of a person in the earlier imperial period; from the late 3rd century it records public office and authority. At this time, the ‘proteuontes’ were probably leading members of the local upper classes with several competences in finance and building activities who reported to the imperial authorities (Zoumbaki 2008, 125-6). If the inscription is from the 4th century, then the title of the governor (anthupatos – proconsul) indicates a date after 324 when the provincial governorship of Achaea that had been downgraded to equestrian rank in the wake of the provincial reforms of the tetrarchy in the late 3rd century (<l>93<n>LSA-93<k>, <l>94<n>LSA-94<k>) was upgraded to the highest rank of proconsul again by Constantine I. FURTHER DISCUSSION The prose form of the inscription is unusual for a provincial governor of Achaea at the period (though not unparalleled). Likewise unusual are some properties of the epigraphic formula, the use of the traditional formula Ψ(ηφίσματι) Β(ουλῆς) (line 4) at the end of the inscription (for a similar case see the Corinthian inscription <l>17<n>LSA-17<k>), and the absence of a signum. This fosters some doubts as to the late antique date of the inscription.

eagleObject.title: LSA 1088

transcription.text: / Fabius Felix / Passifilus Paulinus, / v (ir) c (larissimus) et inl (ustris) , praef (ectus) / urbi, dedicavit.

textHtml.div:
Fabius Felix
Passifilus Paulinus,
v (ir) c (larissimus) et inl (ustris) , praef (ectus)
urbi, dedicavit.

textEpidoc.ab:
Fabius Felix
Passifilus Paulinus,
vir
clarissimus et inlustris , praefectus
urbi, dedicavit.

transcription.commentary: INSCRIPTION In four lines: Fabius Felix / Passifilus Paulinus, / v(ir) c(larissimus) et inl(ustris), praef(ectus) / urbi, dedicavit. 'Fabius Felix Passifilus Paulinus, of clarissimus and illustris rank, urban prefect, dedicated [this]' DESCRIPTION Re-used marble base, with earlier dedication to Diocletian on the back (1257LSA-1257). PROVENANCE AND CURRENT LOCATION The base was discovered in 1589, with two very similar bases dedicated by the same man (1283LSA-1283, 1338LSA-1338), in the vicinity of the church of S. Pietro in Vincoli, on the Oppian hill (CIL VI, 1656). A further base of the same type was found in the same area in the last century (1523LSA-1523). It is thought that this was the site of the main offices of the urban prefect (Chastagnol 1960, 243-251). The base is now lost. HONORAND, AWARDER, AND DATE The subject of the statue is not specified in the inscription, it can be assumed to have been a statue displayed for its historical and aesthetic value. Other dedications of the same type were carried out by the same urban prefect (see 'Provenance and Location'), all of which can be associated with the late antique concern with the embellishment of the city (Lepelley 1994). As we have seen, Fabius Felix Passifilus Paulinus was responsible for a number of dedications during his urban prefecture. This cannot be precisely dated, but certainly fell in the latter half of the 5th century, or even later (PLRE II, 848 Paulinus 13). His name appears on an inscribed marble slab belonging to a late 5th century restoration of the seating of the Colosseum (Orlandi 2004, 499-500). Paulinus as urban prefect is mentioned on an inscribed bronze plaque that opens with the salutation 'Salvis d(ominis) n(ostris)' (CIL XV, 7111), which led Orlandi to suggest 476 (the last year there were two emperors in the Roman world) as the probable terminus ante quem for his prefecture. A later date however is possible but unlikely, since Orlandi correctly points out that the Ostrogothic king Theoderic also appears in inscriptions as dominus noster, but never in monumental or honorific dedications.

hasTranslation.text: Fabius Felix Passifilus Paulinus, of clarissimus and illustris rank, urban prefect, dedicated [this]

eagleObject.title: LSA 0943

transcription.text: / ------- / provin (ciae) ins (ularum) num (ini) (mai) est (ati) q (ue) eor (um) dic (avit)

textHtml.div:
-------
provin (ciae) ins (ularum) num (ini) (mai) est (ati) q (ue) eor (um) dic (avit)

textEpidoc.ab:
-------
provinciae
insularum
numini
mai estati
que
eorum
dicavit

transcription.commentary: INSCRIPTION -------/ provin(ciae) ins(ularum) num(ini) (mai)est(ati) q(ue) eor(um) dic(avit) '... of the province of the islands dedicated to their divine spirit and majesty' The inscription preserves only the last line of a text which must once have included the names of various emperors (cf. 'their divine spirit and majesty' in the inscription) and of the honorand. CIL completed the last word into 'dic(avit)', where 'dic(atus)' or 'dic(atissimus)' appears more appropriate to us. DESCRIPTION No description is given by CIL, and no photo has been published. PROVENANCE/ LOCATION According to CIL, the monument was extant on the island of Cos, without further specification. HONORAND, AWARDER AND DATE The names of the honorands are lost, but the inscription uses a formula very common in the tetrarchic period and therefore probably goes to the Tetrarchs. It resembles closely another inscription from Cos, of which likewise only the last line has survived (942LSA-942). The letter form of that other inscription points to the tetrarchic period, as E. Sironen kindly informs me. Although no picture of the present inscription is known to us, the close resemblance of the two inscriptions entails the tetrarchic date of the present one. The awarder was probably a governor (praeses) of the Islands. FURTHER DISCUSSION The formula of this inscription resembles closely another inscription from Cos, of which likewise only the last line has survived (942LSA-942). Mommsen in 1873 (for CIL III) recorded only the actual inscription; Segre in the 1930s recorded only the other one. I would take the identity of the two inscriptions into consideration; the lettering given by Mommsen (our inscription) and the one given by Segre (942LSA-942), though, differ in too many letters as to take that for sure.

transcription.bibliography: Ritti, T. 'Contributi dell'epigrafia ierapolitana alla conoscenza delle opere figurative', Roman Sculpture in Asia Minor. JRA Supplementary Series 80, Portsmouth RI, 2011 186-8, fig. 11.12
transcription.commentary: INSCRIPTION In eight lines: [Ἀγα]θῆι [τύχηι]. / Κλ(αύδιον) [Μ]ουσωνιανό[ν], τὸν λαμ(πρότατον) /(3) ἔπαρχον τοῦ ἱεροῦ πραι/τωρίου ἡ βουλὴ καὶ ὁ δῆ/μος τῆς Ἱεραπολιτῶν /(6) μητροπόλεως, τὸν ἑαυ/τῶν εὐεργέτην καὶ / κτίστην. εὐτυχῶς. 'To Good Fortune. Claudius Musonianus, of clarissimus rank, the prefect of the sacred praetorium. The council (boule) and the people (demos) of the metropolis of the Hierapolitans (set this up) for their benefactor and founder. With good fortune.' Letter height 3.5 cm. DESCRIPTION (from Ritti 2011, and the published photo) Rectangular marble base, with moulding at the bottom: H 70, W 68.5, D 66.5 cm. The moulding is broken at the front left, and on the left side; the upper rim is chipped, rendering portions of lines 1 and 2 illegible. PROVENANCE AND CURRENT LOCATION Found in the orchestra of the theatre in Hierapolis and first published by Ritti 2011. From the findspot, Ritti 2011, 186 deduces that it was set up in the lower or middle diazoma of the cavea. There is no published record of its present location. HONORAND, AWARDER AND DATE Claudius Musonianus, the honorand, was praetorian prefect of the East in 354-8 (PLRE I, 611-12 Strategius Musonianus). He received his signum Musonianus, alluding to him being inspired by the Muses, from the emperor Constantine I because of his bilingualism. He is also known with the signum Strategius; our inscription adds the nomen gentile Claudius to his name. Musonianus is honoured as a benefactor and founder (εὐεργέτην καὶ κτίστην, lines 7-8). This refer to favours in questions of taxation for which the praetorian prefect was responsible, and to which another inscription from the theatre mentioning Musonianus possibly refers (Ritti 2011, 187-8). He is honoured by the council and people (boule kai demos) of Hierapolis, here styled a Metropolis (line 6).

hasTranslation.text: To Good Fortune. Claudius Musonianus, of clarissimus rank, the prefect of the sacred praetorium. The council ( boule ) and the people ( demos ) of the metropolis of the Hierapolitans (set this up) for their benefactor and founder. With good fortune.

transcription.bibliography: Dittenberger, W., Sylloge Inscriptionum Graecarum. 3rd edition., Hildesheim - New York 1982 no. 897
transcription.commentary: INSCRIPTION In five lines: [τὸν ἡμ]ῶν κ̣ύ̣ρ[ιον] / [ἐπ]ιφανέστατο[ν] / Φλ(άβιον) Κώνσταν / ἡ ἱερὰ Δελφῶν / πόλις. 'The holy city of the Delphians (set this up to) our Lord the most noble Flavius Constans'. This is the text as given in the publication by Jannoray 1946. Vatin 1962 proposes an alternative reading of the imperial name in line 3: [ ] Κωνστάντ̣ιο̣[ν] - 'Constantius' Letter height 2-5 cm. DESCRIPTION (from Jannoray 1946 and the published photo) Rectangular block of coarse grained marble. H 102 cm, W 54 cm, D 49 cm. The block, originally inscribed with a dedication to Carus (282-3), has been turned upside down for the present inscription which begins at the original bottom edge. Between the two inscriptions two lines have been erased which probably once belonged to the original inscription (Jannoray 1946, 260). Substantial breaks at the left side have removed the initial letters of lines 1 and 2. The surface is heavily weathered, making the inscription difficult to read. PROVENANCE NAND CURRENT LOCATION The block was found in 1935 built into a wall of an olive grove some metres to the right of the entrance to the sanctuary of Apollo. It is today in the Delphi Museum, inv. no. 6074. HONORAND AND DATE The inscription's original editor Jannoray identified the honorand as Flavius Iulius Constans, the youngest son of Constantine I. Constans was Caesar 333-7 and Augustus 337-50. The epithet ἐπιφανέστατος (lat. nobilissimus) is usually applied to Caesars, and the inscription is without the title of Augustus; but in Delphi there is another dedication to Constans, as Augustus, which uses the same epithet (930LSA-930). The base was briefly mentioned in a footnote by Vatin 1962 who made the case for reading the imperial name in line 3 as [ ] Κωνστάντ̣ιο̣[ν]] - 'Constantius' rather than 'Constans' and proposed Constantius I as honorand. This would date the base most probably between 293 and 305, the years when Constantius I was Caesar, since in the tetrarchic period the epithet ἐπιφανέστατος - nobilissimus was applied to Caesars, not Augusti. However, Flavius Iulius Constantius (Constantius II) is a third candidate if Vatin's reading is correct. Constantius II was Caesar 324-37 and Augustus 337-61. If he was the honorand, the base will have been set up while he was still Caesar. The inscription was set up by the city of Delphi, proudly styled 'the holy' (line 4). FURTHER DISCUSSION Four further dedications to emperors of the Constantinian dynasty are known from Delphi, two for Constantine I (927LSA-927, 928LSA-928), one for Dalmatius (929LSA-929), and one for Constans (930LSA-930). Vatin, who discussed them comprehensively, believed that they did not form a contemporary group, a conclusion with which we concur (Vatin 1962, 235).

hasTranslation.text: The holy city of the Delphians (set this up to) our Lord the most noble Flavius Constans.

transcription.commentary: INSCRIPTION Partly preserved in 21 lines: Salvis ac propitiis ddd(ominis) nnn(ostris) / Gratiano Valentiniano et Theodosio / invictissimis principibus, / duplici ex more condito decreto, /(5) dicationem statuae maiora iudicia / confirmarunt primo dato d(ivino?) m(andatu?) / T[ha]lassio v(iro) c(larissimo) tunc procons(ule) et nunc / secundo Audentio Aemiliano v(iro) c(larissimo) / vice procons(ule) [---]um magnifica /(10) [---]veteris dig-/nissimum [---] auctorita[te ---] / [---] et apud T[---] / [---]IGA[---]FEIII[---] / [---] pro meritis ac benefici(i)s /(15) in cives remq(ue) p(ublicam) praerogatis vir[---] / [i]n[si?]gnis[---] dignissimo [---] P [---] / patrono Calicio Honoratiano / [---] marmore statuam / [---]EM[---] suae C[---]IVIV[---] /(20) [---]MI[---] / [---] felici[ter---]. 'Our lords Gratian, Valentinian and Theodosius most unconquered emperors, being safe, well, and well-disposed. Established with a decree according to custom twice, the dedication of the statue was confirmed by higher decision first by the issue of an imperial mandate by Thalassius, of clarissimus rank, then governor (proconsul), and now for the second time by Audentius Aemilianus, of clarissimus rank, successor governor (…) eminent (…) worthiest of the old (…) authority (…) and among (…) for the merits and benefits distributed to the citizens and the community (res publica), a man (…) outstanding (…) worthiest (…)to the patron Calicius Honoratianus (…) marble statue (…) luckily (…).' Letter height 5 cm (smaller at the end). We reproduce this mutilated text with the completions proposed by Lepelley 1981. DESCRIPTION (from CIL VIII) Statue base, H 12, W 54 cm. There is no published image. PROVENANCE AND CURRENT LOCATION The inscription was recorded in Medjez-el-Bab, that is the area of ancient Membressa, by CIL in 1881. CIL recorded it lying in front of a rich house in the city centre. There is no recent account of its location. HONORAND, AWARDER AND DATE Caecilius Honoratianus, the honorand, was patron of the city of Membressa (line 17). The name of the awarder is lost in this heavily mutilated text; however, it is probable that it was the city or one of its bodies. Remarkably, the erection of the inscription and statue was twice approved by the imperial administration (see below, 'Further Discussion'). The outer dates of the inscription are provided by the two governors (proconsuls) mentioned in the text: Thalassius (line 7) held office in 377/8 (PLRE I, 887-8 Thalassius 3); Virius Audentius Aemilianus (line 8) in 379/83 (PLRE I, 22 Virius Audentius Aemilianus 4). The statue was set up, as the inscription states, only under the governorship of Aemilianus, when the decree was confirmed for the second time (line 8; see also below, ‘Further Discussion’). FURTHER DISCUSSION As Lepelley 1981, 143 points out, the record of a double intervention of the governor in a local affair is highly unusual. Lepelley suggests that the reason for this must be a conflict between two parties among the decurions, one of which would have denied the honour of a statue to the patron; the double confirmation from the highest authority in the province made sure that the erection of the statue was in accordance with all legal requirements. For differences between locals concerning the erection of an honorific statue, see Symmachus, ep. IX, 115. Symmachus who was governor of Africa in 373-4 was denied a statue by the provincial assembly; he blamed this on the ‘envy’ of one party in the assembly (aemulati). The motif reoccurs in the inscription for Eupeithius in Aphrodisias, probably also a provincial governor (183LSA-183).

transcription.bibliography: Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum; L'Année épigraphique, XI, 4094 1964, 96bis
transcription.commentary: INSCRIPTION In nine lines. Caio Volusio Victor/i, qu(a)estori r(ei) p(ublicae) Oc/riculanorum, IIII/viri (sic, for 'viro') aediles (sic, for 'aedili'), IIIIviri (sic, for ‘viro’) iur/e ed(i)c(undo) (sic, for ‘dicundo’), IIII(viro) quinq(uennali), cives ei (sic, perhaps ‘et’) /(6) plebei hoc emerito stat/uam huic posuerunt, q/ui t(h)ermas (h)iemalis ad pristi/nam dig(nitatem) restauravit et d(e)d(i)c(a)v(it). // (on left side) P(o)s(i)t(a) diae (sic, pro die) III nonas No(vem)b(res). 'To Caius Volusius Victor, quaestor of the city (res publica) of Ocriculum, member of the board of four, aedilis, member of the board of four man with jurisdictional power (IIIIvir iure dicundo), member of the board of four men elected for five years, the citizens and plebeians, this being completed, set up a statue to this man, on account of his service, who restored the winter baths to their former condition and dedicated them. (on left side) Set up on the third day before the Nones of November.' The inscription presents a number of problems, both in terms of mistakes and of the reading of the letters, which are not always unambiguous. The text as presented here is basically the same as in CIL, with a few changes. On l. 5, 'ei' at the end of the lines is considered an improper insertion by the epigrapher in CIL and subsequent editors, but the inconsistencies in this inscription force us to consider the possibility that it might be 'et'. At the beginning of l. 6, the epigrapher originally carved 'plerei', or 'plerii'. This was corrected, but it is not clear whether in antiquity or in modern times. In l. 6, CIL gives 'hoce merito', but we have preferred 'hoc emerito'. If this is correct, it is not clear whether it refers to the completion of the works carried out or to the end of the honorandr's term in office. Parts of the translation offered here are merely tentative. There is no decisive element for dating this inscription in the late antique period. However, a fourth century date is suggested by the paleography, as well as the formulas employed for praising the honorand. This is supported, furthermore, by the history of the building to which our text refers, as illuminated by other inscriptions mentioned below. DESCRIPTION (Photograph) Marble base, with mouldings on top and bottom. The epigraphic field is rough, indicating the erasure of an earlier inscription. PROVENANCE AND LOCATION Our base was found in 1782, during the excavation of the Winter Baths at Otricoli. Other inscriptions certainly from this same provenance, also record works in this complex in 341 (1632LSA-1632, 1633LSA-1633, and CIL XI, 4095). HONORAND, AWARDER AND DATE Caius Volusius Victor was a local notable and civic magistrate, who occupied different functions in the city of Ocriculum. The inscription does not identify his rank or tribe, but he was certainly a member of the local elite, possibly of equestrian rank due to the importance of the magistracies held. It is impossible to be certain about the date when Victor was active. The inscription refers to restoration works carried out in the Winter Baths, part of the bathing complex erected in the mid-2nd century (Pietrangeli 1943, 67-71). Some scholars date Victor's intervention to the period after 341, when the brothers Sextus Cluvius Martinus and Marcus Caesolius Saturninus were responsible for a series of works in this same area (see 1632LSA-1632, 1633LSA-1633, and CIL XI, 4095). In this case, our inscription should be dated to the end of the fourth century, when the baths would probably be in need of new restoration works (Sisanni 2006, 212). It should be noted, however, that nothing of the Winter Baths survives, and that it is impossible to be certain of the date when this complex was originally built. Furthermore, the magistracies occupied by Victor are very traditional, not attested after mid-the fourth century in this area. Later inscriptions recording the setting up of statues in thanks for public works are invariably dedicated to provincial governors or, more rarely in Italy, to defensores. A date in the first half of the fourth century might also be supported by the identity of the awarders of our monument, the citizens and the plebs of Ocriculum: whereas dedications by the citizenry remained normal in the later part of the fourth century, the plebs as a specific group does not usually appear in this period. ACKNOWLEDGEMENT I would like to thank Silvia Orlandi for drawing this document to my attention, and to Ulrich Gehn and Bryan Ward-Perkins, for their assistance with the text of the inscription and its translation.

hasTranslation.text: To Caius Volusius Victor, quaestor of the city ( res publica ) of Ocriculum, member of the board of four, aedilis , member of the board of four man with jurisdictional power ( IIIIvir iure dicundo ), member of the board of four men elected for five years, the citizens and plebeians, this being completed, set up a statue to this man, on account of his service, who restored the winter baths to their former condition and dedicated them. (on left side) Set up on the third day before the Nones of November.

transcription.bibliography: Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum; Fora, M., Epigrafia anfiteatrale dell'Occidente Romano IV. Regio I. Latium , Rome 1996 Granino Cerere, M. G. (ed.), Supplementa Italica, Imagines. Latium Vetus 1, Rome 2005 Inscriptiones Latinae Selectae, XIV, 2080 n. 35 n. 24 6186
transcription.commentary: INSCRIPTION In 13 lines. Valerio Frume/ntio, v(iro) p(erfectissimo), patro/no et defe(n)sori / (h)abitatori cibitatis (sic, for ‘civitatis’), /(5) qui pos(t) multum / temporis aeditio/nem (sic, for ‘editionem’) debotionis (sic, for ‘devotionis’) / renobabit et ite/rabit, pro meri/tu m[unifice]nti(a)e /(11) su(a)e, ordo cibes/que (sic, for ‘civesque’) Laurentum / LL(avinatium). 'To Valerius Frumentius, of perfectissimus rank, patron and protector (defensor) to [each] inhabitant of the city, who after a long period of time renewed and revived the performance of devotion; in merit of his munificence, the council and the citizens of Laurentum and Lavinium [set this up].' 'The 'editio devotionis' in line 6, literally the 'performance of devotion', must refer to the giving of games (often referred to as editiones), which had lapsed for a long period of time. The style of the letters indicates a fourth century date (CIL). DESCRIPTION There is no description available. PROVENANCE AND CURRENT LOCATION The exact provenance of our base is unknown. It is only recorded as being from Pratica di Mare (CIL). It is now in the Musei Vaticani, Galleria Lapidaria, XXXV.14, Inv. Nr. 6978. HONORAND, AWARDER AND DATE The statue was dedicated to Valerius Frumentius, a man of perfectissimus rank and defensor of Lavinium (PLRE I, 375 Frumentius). The statue was awarded by the ordo and citizens of Lavinium.

hasTranslation.text: To Valerius Frumentius, of perfectissimus rank, patron and protector ( defensor ) to [each] inhabitant of the city, who after a long period of time renewed and revived the performance of devotion; in merit of his munificence, the council and the citizens of Laurentum and Lavinium [set this up].

transcription.bibliography: Merkelbach I, no. 2/6/15; I.K. 22,1 (Stratonikeia II,1) no. 1204

Merkelbach, R. and J. Stauber (eds.), Steinepigramme aus dem griechischen Osten. Bd. 1. Die Westküste Kleinasiens von Knidos bis Ilion , Stuttgart 1998 Şahin, M. Ç., Die Inschriften von Stratonikeia. Teil II, 1: Lagina, Stratonikeia und Umgebung (Inschriften griechischer Städte aus Kleinasien Bd. 22, 1), Bonn 1982 221, no. 2/6/15
transcription.commentary: INSCRIPTION Verse inscription of three distichs laid out in six lines, one line for each verse. The inscription is preceded by an invocation to God; it has seven lines in all. At the left margin of the inscription the name Μά/ξι/[μ]ος is carved over three lines (lines 4-6; Cousin 1891). Θεός (line 1) is followed by smaller letters ΗΛΟΥ, which apparently belong to a different inscription of undetermined age (Cousin 1891, 430; Şahin 1982, 167): On the left margin: Μά/ξι/[μ]ος. Θεός. Μάξιμον εἰσοράαις με τὸν ἄστεϊ καὶ ναετῆρσιν / ἡμετέρων καμάτων πολλὰ χαριζόμενον· / τούνεκα δ’ ἡ βουλή με καὶ ἀκτέανοι πολιῆται / (5) στῆσαν κυδαλίμαις εἰκόσι λαϊνέαις / εὐαγέων Χρειστοῖο δόμων προπάροιθε θεοῖο, / ὡς ἀγαθὸν τελέθει μὴ κτεάνων ἀλέγειν. 'Maximus. God. You see me, Maximus who through our toils have given much to the city and its inhabitants. Therefore, the council (boule) and the citizens without wealth (akteanoi polietai) set me up in glorious images of stone in front of the sacred houses of Christ God. How good it is not to care for wealth!' Letter height not recorded. DESCRIPTION (from Cousin 1891) According to Cousin 1891, 429, the inscription is carved on a 'cippus' (‘Cippe’). No further description and no measurements are published; there is no published image. PROVENANCE AND CURRENT LOCATION The inscription was first recorded by Cousin 1891 in the house of Tchillar-oglu Osman in Eskihisar (Stratonicea). There is no recent record of its location. From the wording of the inscription (lines 5-6), it is evident that this base was originally set up in front of a church within Stratonicea. HONORAND, AWARDER AND DATE Maximus, the honorand, was a citizen of Stratonicea (lines 2-3), lauded in several inscriptions in the city (this one, 1200LSA-1200, 1201LSA-1201, and 1202LSA-1202). He is here praised for his generosity. The 'toils, καμάτοι' of line 3 may allude to the liturgies of a civic office holder, that are explicitly described on another inscription (1200LSA-1200); or it may refer to Maximus' wealth which is the result of his toils (as Jones 2009 and Staab 2009, 35 n. 5 take it). He was clearly a devout Christian (lines 1, 6), and his benefactions are explicitly linked in our inscription to not caring for worldly wealth (line 7). The inscription was set up by the council (boule) of Stratonicea and the 'citizens without wealth, ἀκτέανοι πολιῆται' (line 4). These ἀκτέανοι also appear, this time on their own, as the awarders of another statue to Maximus (1202LSA-1202). This may be a way of describing the demos of the city in a manner that would chime with the Christian virtue of aiding the poor, though, in one of the other inscriptions set up to Maximus (1201LSA-1201), the demos is termed in an entirely conventional manner (see also the mention of boule and demos on 1200LSA-1200). In one of the other inscriptions to Maximus (1202LSA-1201) he is praised for having paid, on behalf of poorer fellow citizens, the 'tetraeterikon', a tax demanded every fourth year. This tax was abolished by Anastasius in 498, thereby providing a reliable terminus ante quem for all the dedications to Maximus. The prominent Christian sentiments expressed in all these dedications are unlikely to predate the start of the fifth century, and thereby provide an approximate terminus post quem. FURTHER DISCUSSION This inscription and the other verse inscription to Maximus (1202LSA-1202) were found along with two statues, holding scrolls and with scroll bundles at their legs (Şahin 2008, 53; Şahin 2010, 67). These important, and very interesting, statues are unfortunately at present unpublished. A strongly expressed Christian sentiment is the most striking feature of the inscriptions to Maximus in Stratonicea (1200LSA-1200, 1201LSA-1201, 1202LSA-1202, and our inscription), which sets this remarkable group apart from other honorific dedications. Here, this is supported by the location of the statue in front of a church.

transcription.bibliography: Bauer, F. A., Stadt, Platz und Denkmal in der Spätantike, Mainz 1996 Engelmann, H. Knibbe, D. & R. Merkelbach, Die Inschriften von Ephesos Teil IV. Inschriften griechischer Städte aus Kleinasien, vol. 14, Bonn 1980 424 168, no. 1311
transcription.commentary: INSCRIPTION Verse inscription of one elegiac distich laid out in six lines: εὐδικίης, μώ/λοιο, σαοφροσύνης, / ἀρετάων μάρ/τυς ἐγὼ στή/λη Θεοδοσί/ωι τελέθω. 'Of justice, of toil, of moderation, of the virtues, I, the statue (stele) to Theodosius, bear witness.' Letter height 4.5 cm. The letters are unusually deeply cut. DESCRIPTION White marble base: H 165, W 87, D 72 cm. Monolithic base with integral crown and base mouldings. There are no clear signs of re-use; it is possible, however, since the inscription is cut on an unframed flat surface. Base moulding with small oblique band and larger trochilus, slightly damaged. Shaft with small simple torus at bottom and top, and no frame for the inscription. Crown moulding of middling height, damaged on the left, with one torus and widening trochilus, uppermost band with beak-like acroteria in relief. Top face with cuttings, among them for bronze statue. PROVENANCE AND CURRENT LOCATION Found in front of the baths of Scholasticia (Miltner, 1956), in the debris in front of the apse-facade. Today set up close to its findspot in front of the east corner of the baths. HONORAND AND DATE Theodosius, the honorand, is praised in verse for his justice, toil, moderation and other virtues, core motifs for the praise of governors in Late Antiquity. Although his office is not explicitly stated, Theodosius was probably a governor (proconsul) of Asia. The dedication was attributed to the emperor Theodosius I by Wankel et al. 1980. However, this seems highly unlikely to us. Emperors excel in all virtues through their very office. In inscriptions of the 4th/5th century, it is the eternal and ubiquitous victoriousness of the emperor which is praised, whereas justice and moderation are attributed to imperial magistrates, toiling to spread these virtues - in origin imperial - throughout the empire. Moreover, the verse form would be highly unusual for an emperor in the 4th century, whereas it is constantly used for high imperial officials. Of the men of this name known so far, our honorand is most likely to be identified with the proconsul of Asia who received a statue at Smyrna (486LSA-486) (PLRE II, 1102 Theodosius 16; Malcus 1967, 133-4). There is no way of dating his tenure of office more tightly than within the 4th/5th century. Stichel 1982 thought that the honorand was Theodosius the Elder, the father of the emperor Theodosius I. However, the inscription gives no support to this assumption.

hasVisualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: Last Statues of Antiquity (disclaimer at: http://laststatues.classics.ox.ac.uk/)
Last Statues of Antiquity (disclaimer at: http://laststatues.classics.ox.ac.uk/)

transcription.bibliography: Vostchinina, A., Le portrait romain : album et catalogue illustré de toute la collection / Musée de l'Ermitage, Leningrad 1974 192, no. 77, pls.98-9
transcription.commentary: DESCRIPTION (Object) Over life-size head set on support. H (total): 63, H (of head): 33 cm. Fine-grained marble. The neck is a modern restoration. The nose, chin, right ear, and some locks of hair are also restoration. The hair is carefully rendered on all sides but has drill work only around the face. The beard is carefully engraved. The pupils are U-shaped. The irises are crudely and thickly engraved and do not touch the lower lid. PROVENANCE The Russian empress Catherine II purchased the Lyde Browne collection of Wimbleton in 1787. Two catalogues of the Browne's collections, made in 1768 and 1779, show that he acquired his works from collections (for example, Albani Barberini, Giustiniani, Mattei, and Negroni) in Rome. According to Neverov (fn. 97) this head is one of nine objects from the Palazzi Barberini and Verospi and the Villa Mattei. DESCRIPTION (Subject) The head is a typologically loose version of the Emperor Hadrian (117-138). The combination of the physiognomy and the general form of hair and beard make the portrait immediately recognizable. DATE Eye markings begin to appear in Roman portrait sculpture c. AD 130. The emphatic eye markings on this head are a technique developed in the fourth century AD and are incongruous with the date of the honorand. As many eighteenth century objects on display in Rome, this head may have been refreshed by a contemporary restorer. However, another portrait head of Hadrian (<l>1559<n>LSA-1559<k) from the area of the Ostia has similarly rendered eyes; a portrait of Antoninus Pius was made for the gallery of herms at Welschbillig at the end of the fourth century; and a statue of Marcus Aurelius (?)(<l>1133<n>LSA-1133<k) was re-made in the fourth century in Cyrene. These examples make it possible that this head of Hadrian from the Lyde Browne collection was re-worked in late antiquity, possibly in the fourth century. .

eagleObject.metadataIpr: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported license.
eagleObject.title: LSA 0607

artifact.decoration: clothing: toga, late antique; tunic, colobium; tunic, sleeved

eagleObject.metadataIpr: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported license.
eagleObject.title: LSA 0607

transcription.commentary: DESCRIPTION (Object) Life-size statue. W: c. 50 cm. White marble. The statue is preserved from the base of the neck to the lower shins. The head, the right lower arm and hand, the left wrist and hand, the ankles, most of the set of scrolls near the right shin, the feet, and the plinth are missing. The flat, slightly hollow surface at the neck may indicate that the head was separately worked. PROVENANCE Now in the Kastamonu museum DESCRIPTION (Subject) The statue wears a late antique toga over a long-sleeved tunic (the tunica manicata ), and a shorter short-sleeved tunic colobium . A set of scrolls supports the statue on the outside of the right leg. The body weight appears to rest over the right leg; the lowered right forearm moves away from the body; the left arm, also lowered, is bent at a slightly greater than 90 degree angle. There appears to be no evidence however for a sceptre held in it. The toga is worn in a fashion that is reproduced on four other statues of the period (see 1033LSA-1033, 1034LSA-1034, 1036LSA-1036, 1037LSA-1037). The bottom hem of the long-sleeved tunic is not preserved here; the bottom hem of the colobium crosses the lower legs at the height of the top of the scrolls. The sinus of the toga hangs low and opens between the right thigh and right shin. It then rises to the left forearm around which it is wrapped. The balteus of the toga broadens and covers the left shoulder and most of the upper arm. DATE The date of this statue depends on the form of the toga. The first securely dated examples of the ‘late antique’ toga are the Theodosian imperial family group from Aphrodisias dated bewteen 388 and 392: see 163LSA-163 and 165LSA-165 theodosian group 388-392. The form of the toga of this statue is similar to the Aphrodisian ones in that there is a sinus that opens up in a triangular fashion against the right thigh. Yet the balteus of this statue is much broader and clings tightly across the chest. In actual form the toga here is closest to that of another group of four late togati: 1033LSA-1033 from Constantinople, and 1034LSA-1034, 1036LSA-1036, 1037LSA-1037 from Ephesus. In a scheme of linear development, these four stand between the dated Theodosian togati and the later fifth-earlier sixth century togate examples from Aphrodisias, Pytheas (LSA 147LSA-147) and Palmatus (LSA 198LSA-198). In the statues of Pytheas and Palmatus the opening of the sinus is entirely closed. Thus, the group with the flaring sinus (including the Kastomonu statue) might be loosely dated between the end of the fourth century and the middle of the fifth century. HONORAND The toga was worn by the emperors and the highest imperial officials. A life-size head of an emperor 336LSA-336 has a similar province and has been tentatively identified as Arcadius or Honorius. The find location, suitable body type, and appropriate date are an interesting coincidence.

transcription.bibliography: Donati, A. and G. Gentili, Costantino il Grande. La civiltà antica al bivio tra Occidente e Oriente, Milan 2005 Zevi, F. [et al.]., Museo Archeologico dei Campi Flegrei: Castello di Baia. I. Catalogo generale. Cuma., Naples 2008 288, no. 129 (F. Soriano) 386 (E. Nuzzo: late third to early fourth c.)
transcription.commentary: DESCRIPTION (Object) Medium grained white marble, H 26, W 19, D 22 cm. The head is re-worked from an earlier one for insertion into a statue or bust, as is indicated by a rest of garment at the neck; the neck is now cut horizontally. Traces of the re-working are visible especially around the left ear. The nose is chipped off, the chip extending to the right cheek. There is a shallow break in the hair above the right brow; smaller chips are scattered especially on the chin; the surface is otherwise only slightly weathered. The flesh is smoothly finished. The trimmed hair and beard are indicated by short cuts with a point chisel, running in approximately regular parallel lines from forehead to neck and fringing out slightly above the brow. Hair and beard are standing as a compact mass slightly proud, only on neck under chin and under lower lip incisions are cut directly into the flesh. The eyebrows are indicated by short parallel diagonal hits with point chisel. The iris is circumscribed by an incised line, the pupil is marked by a shallow drill hole. The flesh is modelled by gross inscriptions, as naso-labial folds, two parallel horizontel wrinkles on forehead, and two short vertical lines above the nose; the pronounced lower lip is framed by deep short wrinkles running vertically down from the angles of the mouth. PROVENANCE AND LOCATION The head comes from Cuma, Torre Bizantina. It is now in Pozzuoli, Museo Archeologico dei Campi Flegrei (Castello di Baia), inv. no. 150195. DESCRIPTION (Subject) The mature age of the portrayed is indicated by his full beard and the wrinkles. The head is slightly bent to the left hand side; the eyes are gazing slightly upwards. DATE The expressive concept of the portrait as well as the rendering of the hair indicate a date in the tetrarchic or Constantinian period; the relative harmonization of it’s traits as compared to the early tetrarchic head from Cuma (<l>37<n>LSA-37<k>) resemble the ‘new sublimity’ (‘neue Erhabenheit’, H. P. Laubscher) of the later tetrarchies, early in the 4th century. The technical detail of the rendering of the eyes likewise sets this head apart from <l>37<n>LSA-37<k>; it is a technique to be expected not earlier than ca. 300.

hasTranscription.bibliography: CIL XI, 4180
Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum; XI, 4180

hasTranslation.text: The honey of Leucadius. To Helvidia Burrenia Modesta, granddaughter of Helvidius Burrenus Severus, of clarissimus rank, daughter of Burrenia Severa, woman of clarissimus rank, memorable in chastity, wisdom and innocence among all past [women]; on account of her service and love, the citizens of both sexes of the city of Interamna, with funds collected, [set this up] to their patron after her death. (On the right side): Dedicated on the 18th day before the Kalends of February, under the consulship of Ursus and Polemius. (transl. U. Gehn)

transcription.commentary: INSCRIPTION In 13 lines. Laeucadii Mel. / Helvidiae Burreniae / Modestae, /(4) nepoti Helvidi Burreni Se/veri, v(iri) c(larissimi), filiae Burreniae Se/verae, c(larissimae) f(eminae), pudicitia, sapientia, / innocentia omnibus retro / memorabili, ob meritum amo/remque eius, cives Interam/nanae civitatis utriusque /(11) sexsus (sic) (a)ere conlato post / obitum huius / patronae. // (on the right side) Dedic(ata) XVIII Kal(endas) / Febr(uarias) / Urso et Polemio / co(n)ss(ulibus). 'The honey of Leucadius. To Helvidia Burrenia Modesta, granddaughter of Helvidius Burrenus Severus, of clarissimus rank, daughter of Burrenia Severa, woman of clarissimus rank, memorable in chastity, wisdom and innocence among all past [women]; on account of her service and love, the citizens of both sexes of the city of Interamna, with funds collected, [set this up] to their patron after her death. (On the right side): Dedicated on the 18th day before the Kalends of February, under the consulship of Ursus and Polemius.' (Transl. U. Gehn) In l. 1, Leucadius is a signum, and 'Mel' is here understood as referring to the character of the honorand (see also Andreani and Fora 2002, 52). It is interesting that the inscription only mentions Modesta's grandfather (l.4) on the mother's side and the mother (ll.4-5), and this might be due to the greater importance of this part of the family (Andreani and Fora 2002, 52). DESCRIPTION There is no description available. PROVENANCE AND LOCATION The base was reported as being found in the outskirts of Terni (CIL). It is now lost. HONORAND, AWARDER AND DATE Our inscription records a dedication to a local notable of clarissimus rank, Helvidia Burrenia Modesta. She was a member of an aristocratic family, descendant of patrons of the city and a patron herself (PLRE I, 605 Modesta). There are few statue dedications to female patrons in our period (e.g., 1270LSA-1270 from Rome and 2469LSA-2469, from Africa Proconsularis), although this was more common in earlier times (Chelotti and Buonopane 2008, 645-646). THis was a posthumous dedication, and the emphasis on the family of Modesta's mother suggests that this monument was also a dedication to her ancestors and living relatives. The honour granted to Modesta is also special because, as the inscription informs us, it was decided by 'the citizens of both sexes of the city of Interamna', a unique case for our period. The inscription also mentions that the statue was erected 'aere conlato', suggesting that women have taken part in the collection of funds for this monument, something that is known to have happened in the early empire (see AE 1964, 106 and AE 1998, 416; also Chelotti and Buonopane 2008, 646). Our base is dated to 338, as recorded in the dating inscription on the side.

hasTranslation.text: The honey of Leucadius. To Helvidia Burrenia Modesta, granddaughter of Helvidius Burrenus Severus, of clarissimus rank, daughter of Burrenia Severa, woman of clarissimus rank, memorable in chastity, wisdom and innocence among all past [women]; on account of her service and love, the citizens of both sexes of the city of Interamna, with funds collected, [set this up] to their patron after her death. (On the right side): Dedicated on the 18th day before the Kalends of February, under the consulship of Ursus and Polemius. (transl. U. Gehn)
